1. Hypertension (I10: Essential (primary) hypertension)
Normotensive.
continue:
-DASH Diet
- hydrALAZINE 25 mg oral tablet 25 mg = 1 tab(s), Oral, BID
-losartan 25 mg oral tablet 25 mg = 1 tabs, Oral, Daily
-cloNIDine 0.1 mg/24 hr transdermal film, extended release 1 patches, Topical, Every week
-metoprolol tartrate 25 mg oral tablet 25 mg = 1 tabs, Oral, BID
Will obtain records from cardiologist as they state there is a been a change in the regimen

2. Mixed hyperlipidemia (E78.2: Mixed hyperlipidemia)
LD 72, near goal
Emphasized and counseled on importance of exercise, prudent diet, and importance of weight loss. Further discussed the adherence to healthy lifestyle for maintaining long-term weight goals and minimizing further possible complications of type 2 diabetes. For primary prevention, emphasis regarding adherence to healthy lifestyle is encouraged.
Advised that high risk conditions for future cardiac events include age greater than 65, heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia, history of PCI, diabetes, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, smoking, history of CHF. Cardiovascular risk is enhanced with family history of premature cardiac event, persistently elevated LDL greater than 160, chronic kidney disease, metabolic syndrome, preeclampsia, rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, HIV, persistently elevated triglycerides over 175, and an ABI less than 0.9.
Statin associated side effects may include myopathy, myalgias,elevated liver function tests, and rhabdomyolysis in rare occasions.
Continue with:
-TLC
-Repeat FLP
- atorvastatin 40 mg oral tablet 40 mg = 1 tabs, Oral, Daily

3. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (E11.9: Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications)
Relatively controlled.
Hemoglobin A1c % =7.0
Advised the patient regarding both macrovascular and microvascular complications of diabetes including atherosclerosis, retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy. Also advised regarding dietary modification, exercise, and weight reduction for improving glycemic control. Further advised patient by diabetic specific risk over time includes long duration of type 2 diabetes over 10 years, albuminuria greater than equal to 30 mcg of albumin/ mg creatinine, decreased GFR, retinopathy, neuropathy or an ABI less than 0.9. Ophthalmologist appointment yearly.
Continue with:
- glimepiride 2 mg oral tablet 2 mg = 1 tab(s), Oral, BID

4. Presence of IVC filter (Z95.828: Presence of other vascular implants and grafts)
Patient with a history of IVC filter. Formally patient was anticoagulation however patient had a subdural hematoma and was advised to discontinue anticoagulation; follow-up with hematologist to discuss this as well. He also has evidence of significant normocytic anemia.
Has follow-up with Dr. Montilla and has returned to use of Xarelto 20 mg p.o. daily.

5. Normocytic anemia (D64.9: Anemia, unspecified)
Consistent microcytic anemia. Advised patient follow-up with hematologist as discussed review and recommendations. In addition he was advised to follow-up with GI doctor to follow-up for possible endoscopy or colonoscopy to detect occult sources.
A total of 50 minutes were spent in care of this patient today including:
face-to-face for 45 min
reviewing and tests 5 min
obtaining or reviewing history
performing medically appropriate examination and evaluation
communicating with patient and/or family counseling
We discussed in depth the importance of primary prevention of diseases. I also educated the patient about appropriate lifestyle modifications and other strategies which may improve overall health.

6. CKD (chronic kidney disease), stage III (N18.30: Chronic kidney disease, stage 3 unspecified)
CKD stage III with proteinuria. Patient advised to follow-up with nephrology
Patient with stable CKD stage III. No evidence of edema, shortness of breath, or oliguria. Patient continues on statin. Advised importance of avoiding salt to continue with DASH diet. Avoid hypotensive agents. Dose all medications equivalent for estimated GFR. Protein restriction may be advised to 1 g/kg/day.
Ordered:
Referral Ambulatory, 2023-04-26 10:41:00 EDT, Nephrology, Farias, Antony Adrian MD
7. Lumbar back pain (M54.50: Low back pain, unspecified)
Has element of lumbar stenosis with claudication. We will follow-up with spine center for further review. Physical therapy will be attempted for some relief of pain.
Mild lumbar sprain likely secondary to old injury and improper lifting technique, or misuse. Advised conservative treatment: rest, ice, judicious use of NSAIDs. Discussed with patient importance of light and appropriate lower back exercises or workouts. Advised swimming or low-impact exercise may be appropriate. Further advised if patient develops inability to walk, bowel/bladder incontinence, patient is to go to nearest ER for evaluation and treatment. Advised caution with treatment plan and medications as it may cause drowsiness. Patient verbalized understanding.
Differential diagnoses include lumbar degenerative disc, lumbar spondylosis, sacroiliac joint dysfunction, myofascial pain, somatic dysfunction or facet-mediated pain.
The patient will follow-up with me upon completion of the therapy/exercises, if the pain continues.
We developed an exercise program for core strengthening. I gave the patient an educational book. Lower back exercises pamphlet provided.
Patient is having significant pain caused by back pain which will last more than three days. Trial of NSAIDs and Tylenol has not helped. I believe that it is medically necessary to treat patient’s pain because it is affecting the patient's ability to rest, sleep, and carry out activities of daily living.
E-FORCSE®, Florida Prescription Drug Monitoring Program reviewed online today
Discussed with patient non-opioid alternatives for pain treatment. Discussed the advantages and disadvantages of the use of non-opioid alternatives. Patient provided non-opioid alternative educational pamphlet. Non-opioid alternatives considered were conservative measures such as rest, ice, muscle relaxant, Tylenol, and physical therapy.
Ordered:
Physical Therapy Outpatient Treatment, 2023-04-26 10:42:00 EDT, 2xWeek, 12 weeks, 2023-07-18 10:41:00 EDT, 12, eval and treat
Referral Ambulatory, 2023-04-26 10:47:00 EDT, Spine Center, Guanche, Melissa Marie MD
8. Hand pain, right (M79.641: Pain in right hand)
Mild to moderate right hand pain with lack of function. Would recommend occupational therapy with some improvement.
Ordered:
Occupational Therapy Outpatient Treatment, 2023-04-26 10:43:00 EDT, 2xWeek, 12, weeks, 2023-07-18 10:42:00 EDT, eval and treat
9. Constipation (K59.00: Constipation, unspecified)
Recommended conservative management including patient education, behavior modification, dietary change, fiber (both dietary and supplemental), with adequate hydration and fluids.

value.displayName: Labeling does not contain MRI Safety Information

text.paragraph:
Diabetes Mellitus and Exercise
Exercising regularly is important for overall health, especially for people who have diabetes mellitus. Exercising is not only about losing weight. It has many other health benefits, such as increasing muscle strength and bone density and reducing body fat and stress. This leads to improved fitness, flexibility, and endurance, all of which result in better overall health.
What are the benefits of exercise if I have diabetes?
Exercise has many benefits for people with diabetes. They include:
• Helping to lower and control blood sugar (glucose).
• Helping the body to respond better to the hormone insulin by improving insulin sensitivity.
• Reducing how much insulin the body needs.
• Lowering the risk for heart disease by:
◦ Lowering "bad" cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
◦ Increasing "good" cholesterol levels.
◦ Lowering blood pressure.
◦ Lowering blood glucose levels.
What is my activity plan?
Your health care provider or certified diabetes educator can help you make a plan for the type and frequency of exercise that works for you. This is called your activity plan. Be sure to:
• Get at least 150 minutes of medium-intensity or high-intensity exercise each week. Exercises may include brisk walking, biking, or water aerobics.
• Do stretching and strengthening exercises, such as yoga or weight lifting, at least 2 times a week.
• Spread out your activity over at least 3 days of the week.
• Get some form of physical activity each day.
◦ Do not go more than 2 days in a row without some kind of physical activity.
◦ Avoid being inactive for more than 90 minutes at a time. Take frequent breaks to walk or stretch.
• Choose exercises or activities that you enjoy. Set realistic goals.
• Start slowly and gradually increase your exercise intensity over time.
How do I manage my diabetes during exercise?
Monitor your blood glucose
• Check your blood glucose before and after exercising. If your blood glucose is:
◦ 240 mg/dL (13.3 mmol/L) or higher before you exercise, check your urine for ketones. These are chemicals created by the liver. If you have ketones in your urine, do not exercise until your blood glucose returns to normal.
◦ 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L) or lower, eat a snack containing 15–20 grams of carbohydrate. Check your blood glucose 15 minutes after the snack to make sure that your glucose level is above 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L) before you start your exercise.
• Know the symptoms of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia) and how to treat it. Your risk for hypoglycemia increases during and after exercise.
Follow these tips and your health care provider's instructions
• Keep a carbohydrate snack that is fast-acting for use before, during, and after exercise to help prevent or treat hypoglycemia.
• Avoid injecting insulin into areas of the body that are going to be exercised. For example, avoid injecting insulin into:
◦ Your arms, when you are about to play tennis.
◦ Your legs, when you are about to go jogging.
• Keep records of your exercise habits. Doing this can help you and your health care provider adjust your diabetes management plan as needed. Write down:
◦ Food that you eat before and after you exercise.
◦ Blood glucose levels before and after you exercise.
◦ The type and amount of exercise you have done.
• Work with your health care provider when you start a new exercise or activity. He or she may need to:
◦ Make sure that the activity is safe for you.
◦ Adjust your insulin, other medicines, and food that you eat.
• Drink plenty of water while you exercise. This prevents loss of water (dehydration) and problems caused by a lot of heat in the body (heat stroke).
Where to find more information
• American Diabetes Association: https://www.miller.biz/
Summary
• Exercising regularly is important for overall health, especially for people who have diabetes mellitus.
• Exercising has many health benefits. It increases muscle strength and bone density and reduces body fat and stress. It also lowers and controls blood glucose.
• Your health care provider or certified diabetes educator can help you make an activity plan for the type and frequency of exercise that works for you.
• Work with your health care provider to make sure any new activity is safe for you. Also work with your health care provider to adjust your insulin, other medicines, and the food you eat.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2021-06-14 Document Reviewed: 2021-06-14
Elsevier Patient Education © 2021 Elsevier Inc.
